hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
gpt-4_1-mini_translation:
Puali‘i took hold of the short dagger and then went until he reached the middle where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was stabbing the four sweet potato vines, above the fire. All the children saw this and quickly ran and stood at a distant place out of fear of Puali‘i. Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Hey! Here is the short dagger in my hand; it is the tool to cut off your head today, and then your head will be cooked with the sweet potatoes, and I will eat first, and then you will be free.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not listen to these words of Puali‘i, so Puali‘i spoke a second time. Puali‘i was ready to cut off Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head with the short dagger when at that moment Nāmakaokapāo‘o prayed his death prayer for Puali‘i. It was as follows:  
“My beloved eye of my sliced-off region,  
It is craving, it is trembling,  
Whether to eat or to leave,  
Leave it perhaps to Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  
That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,  
This is my beloved friend,  
Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i,  
Let it be slippery, let it be slippery the eel,  
It is only people and the spear,  
The spear is only with the sheath,  
Nāmakaokapāo‘o will surely die.”
gpt-4_1-mini_commentary:
• The narrative depicts an intense confrontation between Puali‘i and Nāmakaokapāo‘o over the sweet potato vines, symbolic perhaps of a struggle for sustenance or authority.  
  – The use of the short dagger (ko‘ilipi) represents not only physical violence but also a metaphorical threat to lineage or mana (spiritual power).  
  – Sweet potatoes (‘uala) are a staple in Hawaiian agriculture and symbolize life and sustenance, thus the act of stabbing vines suggests destruction of life sources, a grave act of hostility.

• The names of the characters carry deep allegorical meaning:  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o can be broken down as Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o: “The eyes of the puffed or swelling ” or “The many eyes of swelling,” possibly symbolizing vigilance or an enduring watchfulness. The reference to eyes in the death prayer strengthens this symbolism.  
  – Puali‘i, with Pu-a-li‘i, may be interpreted as “The trumpet or sound (pu) of the chief (ali‘i),” aligning him with authority and perhaps a harbinger of judgment or punishment.  
  – Kukui‘aimakaokalani, mentioned in the prayer, combines Kukui (candlenut tree, symbolizing enlightenment and illumination), ai (to eat), maka (eyes), o (of), ka (the), lani (heaven), potentially signifying a divine or higher power overseeing the conflict or a figure of spiritual cleansing.

• The prayer or pule pronounced by Nāmakaokapāo‘o before impending death is rich in metaphor and cultural significance:  
  – The focus on eyes and body parts in the prayer reflects traditional Hawaiian notions of the body and soul as interconnected and the idea of release or transition of the spirit at death (Kanahele, 1986).  
  – The imagery of slippery eel (he‘e) connotes elusiveness and the cyclical nature of life and death, tying to Hawaiian cosmology where the eel is both a real animal and a symbol of transformation (Makālei, 1992).  
  – The repeated notion of “people and spear,” “spear and sheath,” resonates with warfare symbolism and the fragile balance between offense and defense; here, it may allegorize inevitability of death and fate.

• The narrative likely allegorizes a deeper socio-political critique relevant to the Ai Kapu era or the tumultuous period following its abolition in 1819:  
  – The act of cutting and cooking the head (a revered body part) signifies a breach of sacred protocols, possibly reflecting the destabilization of traditional kapu systems and ali‘i authority.  
  – The children’s fear and withdrawal symbolize societal anxiety during transitional phases, as Hawaiian society grappled with new socio-political realities post-contact and early missionary influence.  
  – The invocation of high chiefs and spiritual figures within the prayer suggests a tension between earthly power and spiritual destiny, implicitly critiquing the shifting sands of Hawaiian leadership and cultural erosion in the early 19th century (Kame‘eleihiwa, 1992).

• Numerical symbolism:  
  – The emphasis on the number four in the ‘ehā sweet potato vines may reflect Hawaiian cosmology’s use of four cardinal directions or elements, suggesting the act impacts the entire domain symbolically.  
  – The dual utterances of Puali‘i before Nāmakaokapāo‘o prays correspond to a motif of final chances or warnings given before irreversible destiny, a common narrative device in traditional Hawaiian storytelling (Kanahele, 1986).

• Overall, the passage blends direct narrative with layered allegory to reflect on leadership, spirituality, and cultural upheaval in Hawai‘i’s history, revealing a complex dialogue between tradition and change post-contact.  
  – The ritualistic elements, naming conventions, and poetic prayer all underline the importance of words and acts as carriers of mana and historical memory.  
  – The passage serves as a microcosm of the larger Hawaiian world where authority, spirituality, and survival intertwine, echoing the profound tensions Hawai‘i faced during early 19th-century transformations.

References:  
Kanahele, George S. 1986. *Ku Kanaka Stand Tall: A Search for Hawaiian Values*. University of Hawaii Press.  
Kame‘eleihiwa, Lilikalā. 1992. *Native Land and Foreign Desires: Pehea Lā E Pono Ai?* Bishop Museum Press.  
Makālei, Ka‘ili. 1992. “Symbols of Life and Death in Hawaiian Myth.” Journal of Pacific Studies, Vol. 18.

reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
